News Title: Nahargarh Biological Park loses third big cat to ‘virus’ in eight days | Jaipur News - Times of India
Content: JAIPUR: In what could possibly be a case of gross negligence by Nahargarh Biological Park officials, canine distemper virus (CDV) is suspected to have caused the death of a white female tiger on Thursday, taking the death toll of big cats from CDV to three in eight days. The death of the tiger, aged 14-and-a-half-years, assumes significance as the forest department had administered CD vaccines to six lions and six tigers, including the dead one, on Sunday. On September 19, 10-year-old Asiatic lioness Suzanne, which came to the park from Gujarat, had died. Two days later, nine-month-old tiger cub Ridhi, born to tigress Rambha in December last year, died before the vets could attend to it. Sources said that they suspected both the deaths to have been caused by the CD virus, though, in the case of lioness Suzanne, the paralysed hind legs too may have worsened its condition.In a press statement, DFO Sudarshan Sharma said, “The white tigress which died on Thursday was brought from the National Zoological Park, New Delhi, in 2016. The exact cause of the death is yet to be ascertained. To conduct the post-mortem, a team from Indian Veterinary Research Institute (IVRI), Bareilly, has been called. The team will also carry out the medical examination of other wild cats.” According to sources, if the forest officials had taken timely action and assistance from IVRI earlier, the casualties could have been reduced. They also claimed that more deaths of wild cats were likely at the park. Speaking to TOI, IVRI scientists said, “CDV can spread from one animal to another. The infected animal excretes the virus through all bodily fluids, including urine, as well as larvae from the mouth. The virus also spreads if a big cat eats the meat of an infected animal.” Sources alleged that authorities did not take proper precautions after tests by IVRI confirmed that lioness Suzanne had died of CDV. “This disease gets transmitted easily. Since it’s a viral disease, infected air can also cause it. Infected animals should be isolated from other animals in the zoo and put in quarantine for strict disinfection so that it does not spread. It appears that this exercise was not carried out. Due to this, three deaths have happened in over a week. Let’s hope more such deaths do not occur in the park,” said a senior forest official on condition of anonymity. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: New virus in China: Health ministry seeks info on Indian visa applicants from MEA | India News - Times of India
Content: NEW DELHI: In the wake of the outbreak of an infection in China caused by a new strain of virus, the health ministry has sought from the Ministry of External Affairs details of those who have applied for Indian visa since December 31 so that they can be counselled. The MEA has also been requested to disseminate travel advisory to Indian Embassies in China and adjoining countries in local languages for wider circulation and passenger information, the health ministry said in a statement. The Union health secretary has also written to states and Union Territories to review their preparedness, identify gaps and strengthen core capacities in the area of surveillance, laboratory support and in particular, hospital preparedness in terms of isolation and ventilator management of patients with severe respiratory illness. Special secretary, health, on Monday reviewed the public health measures that need to be scaled in the context of spurt in cases reported by China. According to chinese authorities, coronavirus has infected more than 220 people and resulted in the death of three persons in the country. WHO, in its risk assessment, said that the risk for a global spread of the infection remains low. Various measures have been initiated by the Ministry of Health as a matter of abundant precaution and the secretary, health is constantly reviewing the developments, preparedness and response measures being undertaken by the ministry, an official statement said. The health ministry has written to the civil aviation ministry for thermal screening of passengers at the international airports in Delhi, Mumbai, Kolkata, Chennai, Bengaluru, Hyderabad and Cochin and the airlines to follow International Civil Aviation Organization guidelines for managing and notifying anybody reporting illness on flights originating from China. The Airport Health Organizations at the Delhi, Mumbai and Kolkata have put up signs at prominent locations informing the public about self-reporting of illness. Hospitals attached to these airports have been reviewed for provision of isolation and critical care facilities, the statement said. "The ministry of health has also written to Ministry of External Affairs to provide details of travelers from Wuhan city who have sought visa to travel to India, since December 31 and to counsel the applicants while issuing visa. "They have also been requested to provide daily details. As for E-visa issue Ministry of Home Affairs is being approached," the statement stated. The Joint Monitoring Group (JMG) under the Chairmanship of Director General of Health Services (DGHS) has met twice -- on January 8 and 15 -- to assess the risk and review the preparedness and response mechanisms to manage any case that might get into India. WHO, being represented in the JMG, is providing the ministry with regular updates and technical information. A travel advisory has been put up on the ministry's website and also on the Twitter handle. According to the statement, the National Institute of Virology, Pune, is fully geared up to test samples of novel coronavirus (nCoV). Ten other laboratories under the Indian Council of Medical Research's Viral Research and Diagnostics Laboratories network are also equipped to test samples, if such a need arises. Download The Times of India News App for Latest India News.

News Title: Ahmedabad: ‘Sporadic rain means dengue spike’ | Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content: AHMEDABAD: As the city is battling slow but steady rise in dengue cases this year, experts believe that spells of rain can play a crucial role in deciding how the vector-borne disease in October and beyond will behave. City-based epidemiologist Dr Chitan Desai said that more vigilance is required while treating the water or checking for spots of mosquito breeding this year. “This year, the rain is received in periodic spells — even when you carry out sustained drive and eradicate the mosquito eggs, another spell after a few days can revive the remaining ones,” he said. In an earlier paper ‘Impact of Climatic Fluctuation on Dengue Virus Etiology’ in Journal of Molecular and Genetic Medicine by a team from CHARUSAT in Changa had analyzed the outbreak in 2016 from eight centres in Gujarat and had found that high number of dengue cases was observed when the difference in day and night temperature is above or equal to 2 degrees celsius. The authors had calculated temperature at four times of the day and had found the difference by subtracting the day’s highest and lowest from the number to derive the figure. ‘In January and March this difference is very less, sometimes below 1°C, indicating the role of relatively low night temperature in reducing the dengue instances,’ mentioned the paper. The researchers pointed out two other factors — atmospheric pressure and humidity. ‘The study conducted by other group have shown the large impact of monsoon on dengue incidence, as it is logically connected with the breeding of dengue host in stored rain water. However, In Indian climate, the maximum number of cases was observed post monsoon, suggesting the breeding of vector in stored water in relatively less humid environment,’ mentioned the paper, adding that the most conducive environment is found when the day is warm, night is cool and there is presence of high humidity. ‘The optimal growth rate of epidemics at 33°C implied that many dengue endemic regions would be challenged by increased transmission potential in the future when temperature rises,’ mentioned a study by Joacim Rocklöv and Yesim Tozan published in April this year. The authors also predicted average monthly temperature exceeding 33 degrees celsius in India and African Sahara by 2050. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Ahmedabad: Class XII DPS student succumbs to dengue | Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content: AHMEDABAD: Shockwaves spread through the education fraternity after another child, a class XII students of DPS School in Bopal, succumbed to the dengue virus, which is proving deadly for young students in the city. Sources confirmed that Sreevardhan Dubey, a Class XII student, who was pursuing commerce with maths, succumbed to dengue-related complications on Monday afternoon. “We are saddened by the demise of one of our students to dengue. The student last attended school on September 9 and then was on study leave at home. He had come to school on September 16 to take an exam,” said Unmesh Dixit, officer on special duty at DPS School. Sources said Sreevardhan had got a fever last Monday. When it did not subside, he was admitted to a private hospital on SG Road. He then developed severe complications and finally succumbed. The death comes as another shock for a city reeling from the scourge of dengue. This season has been especially deadly for children, as five children had died due to dengue related complications earlier. According to AMC sources, Manira Qureshi (13) of Behrampura, Hani Patre (12) of Khokhra, Afrinbanu Shaikh (18 months) of Gomtipur, Lokesh Prajapati (4) of Vejalpur and Jay Parikh of Anandniketan School had earlier died due to the virus that is spread by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. Doctors say parents need to be especially careful while sending children to school. “Students should, without fail, apply mosquito repellant. They should wear full-sleeved shirts and full pants, to avoid bites of Aedes aegypti, which bites in the daytime,” said physician Dr Manoj Vitthalani. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Nagpur: Use blood bags with NAT label only, advise experts | Nagpur News - Times of India
Content: NAGPUR: All blood banks and clinicians are aware about the Nucleic Acid Testing (NAT), a highly-sensitive method of testing blood that is used to detect Hepatitis C virus (HCV), Human Immunodeficiency Virus (HIV-1) and West Nile Virus (WNV) in blood. Many blood banks in India have started the practice of providing NAT-tested blood to recipients. But awareness about NAT is still missing. Those who receive blood bags from banks must know about NAT and they should ask for an electronically-printed report of NAT detection while receiving the blood bag, say experts. NAT is a molecular technique for screening blood donations to reduce the risk of transfusion transmitted infections (TTIs) in the recipients, thus providing an additional layer of blood safety. Highlighting the importance of safe blood practices, Dr Rema Menon, in-charge of transfusion medicine at Apollo Hospital, Chennai, who was in Nagpur for IMA’s conference, said that NAT minimizes the risk of transfusion diseases. “NAT test is mandatory, but all blood banks are not equipped with the testing machines. So, there should be a centralized NAT testing centre in every region. All blood banks will benefit from it. This will ensure that patients will get access to NAT blood from any of the blood banks in the region,” she said. Dr Menon also spoke about the two methods of NAT testing. “There are two processes by which NAT test is being done. But, there must be no comparison between these two methods. The circulars issued by regulatory bodies like National AIDS Control Organization (NACO) and National Blood Transfusion Council (NBTC) clearly state that these two are different testing formats and they should not be compared,” she said. Dr Vijay Kumar Tungar, medical adviser of Dr Hegdewar Blood Bank said that recipients deserve NAT-tested blood and many leading blood banks are providing it in the city. “We have appealed to all clinicians in the city to use NAT blood for an additional layer of safety. The methodology of conducing NAT could be different in different blood banks, but the purpose of the test remains the same. We all want to provide safe blood to patients,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Goa scores in curbing spread of Japanese Encephalitis virus | Goa News - Times of India
Content: PANAJI: Goa has fared much better than most Indian states in controlling the spread of the Japanese Encephalitis (JE) virus. Till May, just one JE case was detected in the state. The patient, a senior citizen, has since been cured. Meanwhile, in Assam, data available with the health department has shown that the JE virus has claimed at least 21 lives in the last three months alone. In 2018, three cases of JE were detected in Goa, two of which were children. “Both children, natives of Odisha, had come from their native state and were residing with their respective families in Quepem. Both the children were treated. One child returned to his home state,” said Dr Anant Palyekar, the state in-charge of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme. This year, till date, he said, they haven’t found JE among children. Palyekar said that this year, 37 cases were noted for acute encephalitis syndrome. Since some of the symptoms of JE such as confusion, hallucinations, seizures, weakness and loss of sensation, are common with other illnesses, he said, they could not be ignored. While one case was confirmed, that of the senior citizen, the rest were eliminated after tests results turned out negative. In 2012, there were nine cases of JV detected in Goa. That number reduced drastically to just three cases in following year. Post 2013, there has been a decline in the number of cases. From 2014 and 2017, no case of JE were reported in Goa. While JE is treatable, there can be complications in some percentage of the cases, Palyekar said. Moreover, in case there is a delay in medical intervention, the virus is most likely to leave a residual effect on the survivor, he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Pune: 11-year-old boy dies of dengue | Pune News - Times of India
Content: PUNE: An 11-year-old boy from Koregaon Park died of dengue shock syndrome at Inlaks and Budhrani hospital on September 10, taking the disease death count to two in the city this year. The boy, a resident of Krishna Chambers on North Main Road in Koregaon Park, developed fever on August 31. "His family had consulted a neighbourhood doctor. He was brought to our hospital on September 5," a doctor in the hospital said. He said the boy had no other medical condition. He was put on mechanical ventilation support and died around 10.22pm on September 10. On September 19, a woman from Hadapsar died of dengue-related complications at a private hospital. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Dengue cases up in Tamil Nadu; doctors, health department staff put on alert | Chennai News - Times of India
Content: CHENNAI: With neighbouring states reporting higher number of dengue cases, and fever cases spiking up by nearly 50% within the state, the health department has released an advisory for doctors and local administrators on prevention and early diagnosis of dengue cases. After a review meeting chaired by chief minister Edappadi K Palaniswami on Monday, senior health department officials said the state had about 4,500 fever cases on an average every day, up from the average 3,000. “The spike in fever cases was seen in Chennai, Tiruvallur, Kancheepuram and Cuddalore in the north, Coimbatore, Salem and Erode in the west. The case load is highest in border areas,” said director of public health Dr K Kolandaisamy. As per World Health Organization estimates, about one percent of the population is likely to have fever at any given time. During monsoon and winter, it increases up to 1.5% to 2%. Most of these fevers are common cold and mild seasonal flu. “But dengue, leptospirosis, enteric fever, scrub typhus, malaria and H1N1 also go up. If they are not quickly diagnosed, there can be complications and death,” he said. So far, more than 2,000 cases of dengue and one death have been reported in the state. Officials said test for dengue is done only when the symptoms are severe and patients require hospitalisation. “So, many cases may not have been reported,” he said. The health department has been working with local administration agencies to destroy the habitats for dengue-causing aedes. For instance, Greater Chennai Corporation has been asked to penalise hospitals and institutions up to Rs 10 lakh if they are found to be breeding grounds for aedes mosquitoes. Fines will also be imposed on residential areas, construction sites, educational institutions, and industrial and commercial establishments. Doctors have been advised on how mortality from fevers can be reduced to zero by implementing timely and appropriate clinical management. “Blood samples should be sent for test, paramedical staff should be trained to focus on rehydration and doctors should referral patients to higher centres without delay when there is need,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Row over dengue fogging in Jaipur | Jaipur News - Times of India
Content: JAIPUR: Monsoon is almost over, but Jaipur Municipal Corporation (JMC) is yet to kick-off fogging across the city to check dengue and other vector-borne diseases. Though civic officials claimed that they had completed fogging in half of the city by taking help of ward councillors, there were many who rejected such claims. Last year, Jaipur recorded 42% rise in dengue cases in addition to more than 100 people being affected by Zika virus with Shastri Nagar as its epicentre. According to medical experts, there is an urgent need to start fogging in the city to avoid spread of these diseases. JMC medical Soniya assured that fogging had been carried out in more than 50 per cent of the city areas. “We have started fogging in morning and evening shifts. We have deployed a vehicle and two portable machines for every ward. We have involved councillors so that they could guide us to places where fogging is urgently needed,” said Soniya. She added that JMC had focused on Shastri Nagar and areas around Dravyavati River since both these places could turn out to be larvae breeding bases. Though a few councillors said their areas had been fogged, most of them denied. However, a councillor from Shastri Nagar, who did not wish to be named, said no fogging was carried out. “The area that comes under my jurisdiction had never been fogged. We have asked the JMC to carry out fogging in my area,” the councillor said. In the Walled City, where there are hundreds of dirty lanes which are considered breeding grounds for mosquitoes, special attention is needed. Gopal Saini, a resident of Chandpol said, “As monsoon is almost over, mosquitoes have started to breed again. It has become difficult in the evening. We keep our windows closed and have bought mosquitoe repellents. We have asked our area councillor to start fogging, but it hasn’t been done.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Lucknow: 14 new cases; dengue scores double century | Lucknow News - Times of India
Content: LUCKNOW: Fourteen more people, including two from elite Butler Palace and Dilkusha Garden neighbourhoods, tested positive for the dengue virus on Saturday, taking the patient count to 152 since July and 200 since January. Of the eight men and six women, whose blood samples were examined at KGMU, a 13-year-old girl from Amausi and a 32-year-old man from Telibagh are serious and under treatment at Civil Hospital. Two more patients, residents of Butler Palace and Dilkusha areas, are admitted to private hospitals, but said to be out of danger. The rest are recovering at their respective homes in Ruchi Khand, Indiranagar, Nishatganj, Bangla Bazar, Mahilabad and Utrathiya. As many as 32 more vector dens were found on Saturday. These include Police Line Colony on University Road and pockets of Old Haiderganj, Daliganj, Fazullahganj, Ruchi Khand and Bangla Bazar. Water accumulated in desert coolers, flowerpots and utensils were found to be hosting larvae of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, the carrier of the dengue virus. Yogesh Raghuvanshi, spokesperson for the office of CMO, said teams of LMC and the health department were working to weed out vector dens in Ruchi Khand, from where the highest number of dengue cases have been reported so far. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Government launches Rota virus vaccine drive | Patna News - Times of India
Content: PATNA: The health department launched the statewide vaccination drive for Rota virus from Phulwarisharif primary health centre (PHC) here on Wednesday. Health officials said it will be a part of routine immunization drive conducted by the health department for prevention of diseases like polio. “To save children from diarrhoea, Rota virus vaccine has become part of routine immunization schedule. Diarrhoea and pneumonia are the two major reasons for infant mortality in the state and health department is determined to control both the diseases to further reduce the infant mortality rate. Rota virus vaccine will prove to be a milestone in reducing infant mortality rate in the state,” principal secretary (health) Sanjay Kumar said. Development commissioner Subhash Sharma and executive director of Bihar State Health Society (BSHS), Manoj Kumar, were also present on the occasion. The programme was organized by BSHS in association with Unicef (Bihar). An awareness chariot on dengue and chikungunya was also flagged off on the occasion. Health officials and delegates from WHO, Unicef and CARE were also present on the occasion. “The government has set the target of 90% immunization. Auxiliary nurse midwives, ASHA workers, self-help groups and paramedical staff at PHCs, community health centres and additional PHCs have been trained to achieve the target,” Subhash said and added: “All 633 cold storages in state have been stocked with the Rota virus vaccines.” Manoj said 40% of the children admitted in various hospitals in state suffer from diarrhoea, which mainly occurs due to Rota virus. “Almost 9% of the child deaths below the age of five years is due to diarrhoea. Malnutrition for a long period is also a reason for this. Rota virus vaccine will save at least 33 lakh infants in Bihar from diarrhoea every year,” he said. Altogether 414 crore doses of the vaccine have been administered across 15 states to children. Apart from severe diarrhoea, rota virus infection also leads to high fever, vomiting and stomach ache. Loose motion and other symptoms remain for 3 to 7 days and if not given proper medication, it can lead to severe dehydration and even death. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Construction sites and parks new dengue vector dens | Kanpur News - Times of India
Content: Puddles dotting construction sites and parks along Kanpur Road and Hardoi Road are breeding grounds for mosquitoes, residents told TOI on Saturday during a reality check on why the number of dengue cases are so high in these areas. Since July, 152 people in the city have tested positive for the vector-borne viral disease and 67 of them or 44% belong to residential neighbourhoods along the two arteries. Also, 37% of the total vector dens identified so far are in these areas. TimesViewThe drive to eliminate Aedes aegypti breeding grounds has not been able to prevent the outbreak of dengue fever this year. Money and efforts will go waste if the authorities allow water to accumulate on vacant plots and at construction sites along Kanpur and Hardoi roads. Such vector dens are also present elsewhere in the city. The department and LMC must work in tandem to sanitise these placesResidents contended that urban expansion was the key reason behind the spurt in dengue fever. The civic authorities, they said, were trying to contain the mosquito population through fogging and anti-larval sprays, but the exercise was concentrated in places where people live. Vacant plots, construction sites and parks are rarely covered during these drives. “Whenever a dengue case is reported, there is a spurt in sanitising activities. However, no follow-up is done,” said Shivam Mishra, a resident of Rajini Khand. Rajesh Kumar of Ruchi Khand, whose brother tested positive for dengue fever in August, said the civic authorities cleaned the area and sanitised homes, albeit for a brief period. “No wonder four more persons had dengue last week. Since repeated requests to the authorities fell on deaf ears, residents are themselves pouring kerosene oil on puddles to kill mosquito larvae,” Kumar said. Three members of Arti Singh’s family suffered from dengue fever in September. “The agencies cleaned up the area and issued notices to households where larvae were found. However, nothing was done against owners of four vacant plots and three construction sites, which are also breeding mosquitoes,” she said. Anupam Bisariya, a theatre artist in Rajajipuram, said three labourers working at an under-construction building in the area contracted the dengue virus this month. “We called the local corporator, but he blamed the owner of the property. We demand that the authorities clean puddles and waterfilled potholes for public safety,” he added. In-charge of the district’s vector-borne disease control unit Dr KP Tripathi said, “Teams will be instructed to eliminate mosquito larvae in parks, construction sites and vacant plots. Owners will be served notices too.” Nagar Swachhta Adhikari Pankaj Bhushan said zonal officers would be asked to clean parks. “Penalty will be levied on owners and contractors who are held accountable,” he added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Ahmedabad: Do bigger Zika worries lie ahead? | Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content: AHMEDABAD: A recent World Health Organisation (WHO) bulletin on the Zika virus disease in India, spread by the Aedes aegypti mosquito, has drawn the attention of epidemiologists to the question of wwhether India’s Zika outbreak in Rajasthan and MP and detection in Ahmedabad and Chennai is part of a pattern of smaller localized outbreaks or the beginning of something bigger? The bulletin points out that prior to the Rajasthan and MP outbreaks last year, there were three Zika virus cases in Ahmedabad in 2016 and 2017, the first in the sub-continent. Low levels of population immunity may therefore be expected, the bulletin states. The WHO bulletin quotes Dr Neena Valecha, director of the National Institute for Malaria Research in New Delhi, “The situation is a matter of concern,” says Valecha, but she is hopeful that the government’s vigorous response, and increased surveillance will be sufficient to track and reduce transmission to a minimum. Zika virus’s risks of causing microcephaly in newborns will be an important focus of India’s Zika response in the coming months, the WHO bulletin states. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Viruses ‘hack’ molecular biological system | Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content: AHMEDABAD: Viruses such as HIV — responsible for AIDS — are difficult to deal with. How they enter human cells and how they multiply and manipulate the human immune system have been studied over the years to find a cure. A new research published in journal 'Scientific Reports' by the Nature Research points at a mathematical model of the spread where the viruses target the nodes for maximum control of the signalling network in human cells. The paper, “Network controllability analysis of intracellular signalling reveals viruses are actively controlling molecular systems”, was recently published in “Nature”. A senior research fellow at Dhirubhai Ambani Institute of Information and Communication Technology (DAIICT), Dr Vandana RaviA new research published in journal 'Scientific Reports' by the Nature Research points at a mathematical model of the spread where the viruses target the nodes for maximum control of the signalling network in human cells.ndran, was one of the lead authors. Other team members included Prof V Sunitha from DAIICT and researchers from Toho University in Japan, University of Glasgow, and University of Manchester in the UK, and IIIT-Delhi. “Human cell is a complex organism. When it interacts with viruses — which can’t live on their own, changes happen at both the sides,” said Ravindran. “The viruses try to hijack the entire system, but how does that happen? Viruses choose the driver nodes in our molecular systems to gain access to the complex network. The principle is known as control theory in data sciences.” The process can be compared to how hackers identify a central computer system and attack it to gain access to a large network of computers to infect it. The team studied the pattern in both HIV and Hepatitis C viruses by carrying out experiments in both infected and normal systems. “The research gives us a peek into the complex system through which the viruses interact with human proteins and the dynamics governing the spread and intensity,” said Ravindran. “Application of this computational biology can be found in drug delivery system and identifying anti-viral targets.” Ravindran is currently a research fellow at The Royal Society as part of two-year Newton International Fellowship under which she got a grant of GBP 91,192 (approximately Rs 82.23 lakh) for her post-doctoral research, “Modelling viral-host molecular interaction using control theory”. The paper argues that a virus efficiently brings the dynamically organized host system into its control by mostly targeting existing critical control nodes, requiring fewer nodes than in the uninfected network. The lower number of control nodes is presumably to optimize exploitation of the sub-system required for virus replication and host response to infection. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Nandankanan zoo elephant dies in Odisha capital | Bhubaneswar News - Times of India
Content: BHUBANESWAR: A male elephant of Nandankanan zoo Chandan died here on Sunday due to virus attack. Despite treatment being offered by the veterinarians, the animal didn’t survive. Zoo deputy director Jayant Das said the pachyderm’s appetite reduced suddenly and nasal discharge was seen. Thereafter, veterinary doctors started treatment. “The death was due to herpes virus infection. To ascertain other causes of death, sample from the carcass has been collected for autopsy,” said Das. He added that due care is being taken to check spreading of the virus. After its death, the zoo currently has six elephant. Chandan had been rescued from Chandaka wildlife sanctuary and brought to Nandankanan in August, 2010. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: More diagnostic centres needed in Telangana: Amicus curiea tells HC | Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content: HYDERABAD: Highlighting the severity of dengue outbreak and growing concerns over the number of cases, the high court was informed that Telangana has just two diagnostic centres in Hyderabad to test and detect diseases like dengue, swine flu and malaria. Amicus curiae S Niranjan Reddy said the time has come to set up eight diagnostic centres across the state to fight the diseases. Asserting that Telangana should not lead a lone battle against dengue and other diseases, he said the state should make use of the expertise of the central government and the National Vector Borne Disease Control Agency (NVBDCA). Stressing the point that only two centres — one at the Institute of Preventive Medicine (IPM) and the other at Government Fever Hospital in Nallakunta — would be of little use to control the spread of the diseases, Niranjan suggested that the number of diagnostic centres should immediately be increased. He was making these suggestions while assisting the court in the hearing of a PIL which challenged the alleged inaction of the government to prevent and control the spreading of dengue, chikungunya, malaria and other diseases. A bench of Chief Justice Raghavendra Singh Chauhan and Justice A Abhishek Reddy on Friday heard the PIL filed by advocate Rapolu Bhasker Netha. The amicus curiae, in his report, further said the government should coordinate with specialised agencies lile NVBDCA and National Institute of Malaria Research, working under the Union ministry of health and family welfare. Both the ministry and World Health Organisation (WHO) had issued clear guidelines on the diseases and the state should follow them, the senior counsel said. “A comparitive study of steps taken by various governments to control these dreaded fevers could also serve the purpose,” the senior counsel said, citing the example of Punjab, which in coordination with WHO, had developed a micro-strategic action plan for elimination of Malaria between 2018-2020. A specific action plan for swine flu detection and eradication should also be prepared, he said. Niranjan felt there was no coordinated effort among the authorities of various wings to deal with the health problems. All the registered diagnostic centres and doctors should be informed about existing swine flu detection facilities and the protocol to be followed on collection of blood samples, etc. “Early detection will certainly arrest the spread of these vector-borne diseases,” he said. Apart from organising awareness campaigns on mosquito menace, dissemination of information to people and medical fraternity on these diseases was vital both in prevention and treatment, he added. The court had sought assistance of Niranajan to issue certain guidelines to the authorities concerned. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Colleges, fire station among 35 new vector dens in Lucknow | Lucknow News - Times of India
Content: LUCKNOW: Two reputable colleges and a fire station were among 35 places in the city found to be breeding the larvae of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, a carrier of the dengue virus, on Thursday. Five more persons, including a three-year-old boy, also tested positive for the disease, taking the dengue case count to 67 since July and 115 since January. The new patients are from Khadra, Banglabazar, Ruchi Khand, Indiranagar and Sarojininagar. They are all out of danger. The health department's surprise inspection covered 1,088 spots in 11 areas and found the larvae at Christ Church College in Hazratganj, Kalicharan Degree College in Thakurganj, Chowk fire station and 32 houses. In the colleges and fire station, water accumulated in desert coolers was serving as the breeding ground. In residential buildings in Rajajipuram, Haidarganj, Chowk, New Haidarganj, Cantt Road and Lalkuan, the larvae were found in discarded utensils, water tanks, and flowerpots. ACMO DK Bajpai said they were conducting door-to-door campaigns and programmes on academic campuses to "generate mass awareness". Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Dengue claims two more, Telangana government cagey on death toll | Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content: HYDERABAD: The dengue virus that has been sweeping across Telangana for the past few months has claimed two more lives in the city on Thursday. The death toll has gone up to 56 this year so far as authorities grapple to find ways to combat the deadly fever. According to the government, all these deaths have been put under a list of 'suspected dengue deaths' and is being re-verified by an audit team. But the health department has admitted that there was a spurt in the spread of the virus since June 1, with 10,876 dengue cases reported from across the state. Among the patients who succumbed to the virus on Thursday is a 30-year-old woman, Anusha Kohmineni, from Kapra. She died at city-based Yashoda Hospital. "She was brought in a collapsed condition to us, and she succumbed on Thursday morning," an official said. The second patient, a 62-year-old man from Sainikpuri, also died of the virus at city-based Srikara Hospital, health authorities said. Health department sources said an 11-year-old boy died at Gandhi hospital of suspected dengue, but authorities said they would have to verify the death.  In yet another death related to the seasonal diseases, a two-and-half-year-old baby succumbed to 'viral fever with thrombocytopenia' at Ankura Hospital, confirmed the health facility authorities. His condition was characterized by a drop in platelet count, much like that in dengue. "The child was suffering from fever since three days and had low platelet count which resulted in the patient going into shock," said an official. With a large number of influenza and viral fever cases being reported across the state and doctors pointing out that younger patients are especially vulnerable, and finding it difficult to recover, youngsters and the elderly need to be monitored closely, said out experts. There should not be any delay in seeking medical attention in case of any fever, advise doctors. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Union health ministry directs Kerala to undertake enhanced surveillance for Nipah virus in animals, livestock and bats | Kozhikode News - Times of India
Content: KOZHIKODE: The Union health ministry has asked the state government to develop a mechanism for enhanced surveillance for Nipah virus infection in animals/ livestock and in bats in the wake of Kerala witnessing Nipah infection for the second year in a row in May- June 2019. The directive has been issued after the tests conducted at the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune identified presence of Nipah virus infection in 12 of the 36 Pteropus fruit bats (33%) collected from the districts of Idukki and Thrissur following Nipah infection reported in a 23- year old man this year. The first Nipah outbreak in the state in May 2018 had claimed 17 lives in the districts of Kozhikode and Malappuram. In a letter to state principal secretary (health) Dr Rajan N Khobragade, Lav Agarwal, Joint Secretary of Union Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, has asked Kerala government to develop a mechanism for enhanced surveillance for Nipah virus infection in animals/ livestock and in bats by the state Animal Husbandry and Wildlife departments respectively for mapping hotspots (areas which have higher risk of infection) and to provide early warning signals to public health authorities. The state government has also been asked to increase fever and Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES) surveillance in health facilities and capacity building of all concerned. "The Ministry of Health and Family Welfare is also coordinating with the Department of Animal Husbandry and Department of Wildlife for strengthening surveillance in both humans and animals (both domestic and wildlife) with regular data sharing for identifying hot spots and also for detecting early warning signs for planning preparedness and response strategies," the letter said. The Centre has also asked to increase awareness among public about the modes of transmission of Nipah virus and the precautionary measures to be taken. This year a 23- year old man hailing from North Paravur was tested positive for the disease. The index case was however discharged after 54 days of treatment in a hospital in Ernakulam and the district was declared Nipah virus free on July 23, 2019 The principal secretary has forwarded the letter to the Director of Health Services and to the Animal husbandry and forest departments for necessary action. Fruit bats of the family Pteropodidae- particularly species belonging to the Pteropus genus- are the natural hosts for Nipah virus. Nipah virus can be transmitted to humans from animals (such as bats or pigs), or contaminated foods and can also be transmitted directly from human-to-human. Outbreaks of the Nipah virus in pigs were reported during the initial Malaysian outbreak in 1999.The presence of Nipah virus antibodies have also indicated that dogs, cats, goats and horses were infected during the outbreak in Malaysia, but only if exposed to infected pigs. Their role in transmitting infection to humans was not determined. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Dengue cases cross the 100 mark since January, but fogging squads missing in action | Lucknow News - Times of India
Content: LUCKNOW: The number of dengue cases in the city since January touched 110 on Wednesday to mock official claims of concerted efforts to eliminate vector dens. Time and again, the health department has said it has sprayed larvicide since July to contain breeding grounds of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which carries the dengue virus. The Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC), on the other hand, swore by fogging drive across all the 110 wards. “As many as 23 vehicles mounted with fogging machines are on the job. Every locality is being covered once a week. Where the vehicles cannot reach, our workers on cycles are conducting fogging,” said LMC health officer SK Rawat. However, when this newspaper spoke to citizens, many contested the claims. Team TOI also spotted puddles, drains and swamps that could be breeding the dengue larvae. Residents of Chowk, Thakurganj, Gomtinagar, Indiranagar, Mahanagar, Hazratganj, Aashiana, Vikasnagar and Jankipuram said their neighbourhoods had not seen fogging in the past two months. “No drive has been carried out here to contain the sting menace. I live on the sixth floor and there are mosquitoes in my apartment,” said Pallavi Singh, who lives in a high-rise in Aashiana. Ankur Tiwari of Eldeco Greens in Gomtinagar said his colony had not been fogged even once this year. “Repeated complaints to LMC has fallen on deaf ears,” he said. In areas where fogging has been carried out, people complained that the insecticide used to kill mosquitoes was ineffective. Others said the fogging squad never followed up the drive, necessary to make the exercise effective. “There should be health officers monitoring the exercise. We don’t know what chemicals are used. Fogging, if done, hasn’t worked,” said Vijay Gupta of Indiranagar. Vikasnagar residents said fogging was done only on the main road. Lanes were left untouched. Jyoti Tripathi of Mahanagar said houses of politicians and bureaucrats alone were being sanitised. Health officer Rawat denied the allegations and said chemicals were being used as per standard norms. “The population density of mosquitoes has reduced this monsoon compared to last year. Corporators accompany workers during drives. If people have complaints, they can get them registered at our grievance cell. We are committed to fogging,” he said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: 13 more have dengue; virus tightens grip on Kanpur Road | Lucknow News - Times of India
Content: LUCKNOW: Localities along Kanpur Road, particularly Aashiana and Ruchi Khand, continued to top the list of places being stalked by dengue fever. Of the 13 people who tested positive on Friday, three are from these areas. The rest are from Indiranagar, Daliganj, Ramleela Maidan (Sadar), Bangla Bazar, Salehnagar, Chinhat, Shardanagar, Telibagh and Rajajipauram. In fact, 36 of the total 138 cases reported this monsoon are from areas along Kanpur Road. Among the recent patients (nine men and four women), the condition of 10 is serious. While seven are under treatment at civil hospital, three are admitted to Balrampur hospital. The rest are recovering at home. Yogesh Raghuvanshi, spokesperson for the office of chief medical officer, said workers of voluntary outfit ASHA and auxiliary nurse midwives, who were earlier deployed for pulse polio, were being reassigned to the vector control programme. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Kalyan: Ex-KDMC mayor dies of suspected swine flu | Thane News - Times of India
Content: KALYAN: 49-year-old Kalyani Patil, Ex-mayor of KDMC (Kalyan-Dombivli Municipal Corporation) died due to suspected swine flu during her treatment at private Jupiter Hospital in Thane. Patil was associated with Shiv Sena and she twice was elected as corporator in KDMC. She during 2013 to 2015 served as Mayor of KDMC. She was brought to Jupiter Hospital last month on August 14 with respiratory failure due to pneumonia. In Officials statement hospital said she was diagnosed to have H1N1 infection. Her condition was critical due to pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) affecting her lungs. The statement further said she was kept in a negative pressure room in the ICU and was on ventilator support throughout her treatment. She was managed by a team of chest specialists, intensive care specialists and nephrologists. Despite all efforts as per medical protocols, she succumbed to her illness due multi-organ failure on Tuesday afternoon. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Former mayor of Kalyan-Dombivli succumbs to H1N1 | Thane News - Times of India
Content: KALYAN: A former mayor of Kalyan-Dombivli Municipal Corporation (KDMC), Kalyani Patil, succumbed to H1N1 infection on Tuesday, making her the latest victim of the viral disease in the Mumbai Metropolitan Region. Patil, who was associated with Shiv Sena and was twice elected as a corporator in KDMC, was undergoing treatment at a private hospital since August 14. Authorities at Thane’s Jupiter Hospital said that the 49-yearold was admitted there with respiratory failure due to pneumonia. She was subsequently diagnosed with H1N1 infection, earlier known as swine flu. “Her condition was critical due to pneumonia and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) affecting her lungs. She was on ventilator support throughout her treatment,” said the hospital spokesperson. The hospital added that Patil succumbed due to multiorgan failure and septic shock with ARDS on Tuesday afternoon. Patil’s last political stint was as KDMC mayor from 2013 to 2015. H1N1 has claimed 208 lives in the state this year, while over 2,200 people have been affected by the viral disease. The state had recorded 462 deaths in 2018 and 778 in 2017. State officials said that the cases and deaths have come down since an epidemic-like situation seen during March and April. “We saw majority of deaths in March and April. For instance, there were as many as 66 deaths in April alone. However, in the following months, deaths have dropped to single digit,” said Dr Pradeep Awate, the state epidemiologist. Awate said that seven deaths were reported in June and five in August. “Cases and deaths are sporadic now. This is perhaps the first death in September,” he said. Mumbai has reported four H1N1 deaths this year and over 300 cases. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Scrub typhus, swine flu claim 2 lives in Hadauti | Jaipur News - Times of India
Content: KOTA: Scrub typhus claimed life of a 50-year-old man in Kota on Monday, while another 25-year-old woman from Namana village in Bundi district died of swine flu on Sunday after she was tested positive with H1N1 virus. Six other fresh cases of scrub typhus were detected in Kota on Monday. The medical experts have, however, termed the current strain of swine flu to be ‘less lethal’ and recommended precautionary measures against scrub typhus that generally appears to stronger during rainy season. Shiv Prasad, a resident of Khanpur town of Jhalawar district, was tested positive with scrub typhus and was undergoing medical treatment at MBS Hospital in Kota. Shiv Prasad died during treatment on Monday morning. On Monday, as many as six fresh cases of scrub typhus, including three from Kota, two from Bundi, one from Baran were detected, besides nine cases of dengue. Refuting swine flu death in Kota in recent days, Kota CMHO B S Tanwar said that the patient died of swine flu on Sunday was from Bundi and claimed no death of swine flu was recorded in Kota in recent days. Swine flu has claimed 16 lives this year since January and 269 cases detected in Kota district, while scrub typhus so far counts 23 cases and zero death with one doubtful one as medical audit has not yet cleared the reason of death, the CMHO said. Ramdhani Meena, a resident of Namana village in Bundi district, had been taking medical treatment at her home after medical check-up at Kota’s new medical college hospital, told deputy chief medical and health officer, Bundi, Dr Avanish Sharma. Meena died on Sunday and medical test report from new medical college hospital, Kota confirmed her to be tested with H1N1 virus after her death on Sunday, he added. At least 22 persons have so far been detected with swine flu virus in Bundi district since January this year and other 6 have so far died of swine flu in the district, the Dy. CMHO said adding scrub typhus has counted 17 positives and zero death in Bundi district. There are sporadic cases of swine flu probably caused by its virus’ post outbreak persistent in the community and travel, however, ‘it has been observed the new strain of H1N1 virus is not so lethal as previous one used to be and can be checked and treated on detection and medical care in time, told Manoj Saluja, senior professor in medicine in Kota medical college, he further added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Delhi registers 202 malaria cases this year with 48 in 1st week of September | Delhi News - Times of India
Content: NEW DELHI: Nearly 50 cases of malaria have been reported in the first week of September taking the total number of people affected by it in the national capital this year to over 200, according to the latest municipal report. The number of dengue cases recorded till September 7 stood at 122, with 30 of these reported this month and 52 in August. Of the 202 malaria cases, 48 were reported in September, 56 in August, 54 in July, 35 in June, eight in May and just one case in April. According to the report released on Monday, 40 cases of chikungunya have also been reported this year. Last year, 2,798 dengue cases and four deaths were recorded by the South Delhi Municipal Corporation (SDMC), which tabulates the data on vector-borne diseases in the city. Both the Delhi government and the local bodies have been making efforts to raise awareness on precautions to ensure that there is no breeding of mosquito larvae around them. The Arvind Kejriwal government has started an anti-dengue campaign '10Hafte 10Baje 10Minute' urging people to inspect their house for any standing water. The campaign -- from September 1 and November 15 -- to combat dengue has garnered support from several personalities, including cricket legend Kapil Dev, many Bollywood actors and well-known journalists. During a press conference on Sunday, Kejriwal had said, "In five years, the number of dengue cases reported have come down by 80 per cent. We have tried to reduce it even further. This year, fortunately, there is no spike in it and it is because all people have come together, from Delhi government to Centre and MCD". Dengue mosquito larvae breed in clear, standing water while those of malaria mosquito thrive even in dirty water. Doctors have advised people to take precautions and ensure that there is no breeding of mosquito larvae around them. They have urged people to wear full-sleeves and use mosquito nets. Water coolers should be dried up when not in use as mosquitoes carrying dengue virus usually breed there, a doctor said. Cases of vector-borne diseases are usually reported between July and November, but the period may stretch to mid-December. Meanwhile, mosquito-breeding has been reported in at least 1,06,948 households and 90,461 legal notices have been issued this year. Last year, 473 cases of malaria and 165 cases of chikungunya were reported. According to the SDMC, 10 people had died due to dengue in Delhi in 2017, of whom five were not residents of the national capital. Overall, the vector-borne disease had affected 9,271 people in the city in 2017. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: H1N1 death in Thane: TMC intensifies awareness drive | Thane News - Times of India
Content: THANE: The civic-health department has intensified its campaign to combat H1N1 virus by taking various initiatives like informing people regarding the dos and don'ts to prevent themselves from getting infected with the virus. The civic body has so far recorded around 49 H1N1 positive patients, including two deaths and it was seen that most of these patients were the ones who had travelled out of the city or are high risk patients. Citizens are asked to look out for symptoms of virus - body ache, congestion, breathlessness, loose motion, chest pain, drowsiness, etc. and immediately consult the doctor. Also, it is expected that if they are infected, then they should do a swab test and start medication. "Some of the precautions that people can take are avoid going to crowded places, wear a mask, wash their hands, get adequate sleep and maintain a healthy diet," said Dr Ram Kendre, medical health officer, TMC "We are doing the swab tests of suspected patients and if the reports are positive, then we are urging them to stay in isolation," he added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Virar woman third H1N1 casualty this year, 40 positive cases in February | Mumbai News - Times of India
Content: MUMBAI: A 46-year-old Virar resident died of influenza H1N1 at Kasturba Hospital in Chinchpokli this week, making her the year’s third casualty of the viral disease from Mumbai Metropolitan Region (MMR). In a clear sign that the respiratory virus is back this year, BMC confirmed it had recorded 40 cases in February from the city. The positive cases detected in 28 days of the last month was nearly double that of all cases in 2018 (25). TOI has learnt that at least six patients have died of H1N1, initially called swine flu, in city hospitals. But, barring one, most were out of Mumbai cases, referred only for medical treatment. The previous two cases were in Palghar and Thane. A BMC official said the suspected H1N1 casualties will be reviewed by the death committee on March 5. Across the state, nearly 30 have died so far. The respiratory infection that starts with cold, cough and fever can progress into a serious life-threatening lung condition if not treated on time. At least 15 states are reeling under the virus’ onslaught, with Rajasthan and Gujarat recording the most deaths. Dr Sujeet Singh, who heads National Centre for Disease Control (NCDC), New Delhi, said cases were coming from all over the country and an extended winter probably had a role. Priyanka Konapalkar (46) succumbed on February 24 at Kasturba Hospital in less than 24 hours of hospitalisation. A relative said she came down with classic flu symptoms about a week before her death. She sought treatment at a local hospital before getting admitted to Virar’s Sanjivani Hospital in a breathless condition. She was put on ventilator support there. “Her condition kept deteriorating. Doctors told us she needed care in a higher centre, so we took her to Kasturba,” said Mayur Merai, a family friend. He added that Konapalkar’s family was given preventive treatment by Vasai Virar Municipal Corporation. Infectious disease consultant Dr Om Srivastava said the virus was very much in the area. “The volume of H1N1 patients doctors are treating has climbed. It is significantly higher than last year. Timely treatment is the key as not everybody requires hospitalisation or ICU,” he said. “Quite a few who got the infection this year had taken the vaccine. A variant of H1N1 is probably circulating. But that number is minuscule, and vaccination is recommended,” he said. A BMC official said civic hospitals have sto cks of oseltamivir. “We last had a spurt in February 2015. We hope with rising temperature cases will go down,” the official said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: AES virus: Litchis disappear from Odisha markets | Bhubaneswar News - Times of India
Content: BHUBANESWAR: Litchis vanished from the markets in Odisha on Wednesday a day after the government ordered a laboratory test to ensure the fruit doesn't carry the deadly Acute Encephalitis Syndrome (AES) virus after reports emerged linking litchis to the AES outbreak that has killed more than 100 children in Bihar so far. "Summer has gone and so are the litchis," said Ramesh Sahu, a vendor at Kharavela Nagar in Bhubaneswar, trying to avoid queries on the disappearance of the fruit from the market. Bhaskar Patra, a fruit seller in Unit-I market, said vendors have disposed of the fruit fearing presence of AES virus in it. "Nobody knows whether the litchis were infected or not. We did not want to take any risk," Patra said. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: In Hyderabad, all four dengue variants bare fangs | Hyderabad News - Times of India
Content: HYDERABAD: Doctors have called for a molecular monitoring of dengue as all the four variants of the virus that are in co-circulation in Hyderabad and other parts of India are likely to emerge into recombinant virus strains posing more danger to people. Viruses are known to exchange genetic material and since all the four strains of dengue virus are in co-circulation there is a risk of emergence of newer potent variants. Already in the last three years a new variant of dengue virus had emerged with a new serotype, making it difficult for doctors to keep dengue under check. The recent spurt in dengue cases is also attributed to changes in genetic make-up of the virus. “There are high number of severe dengue cases in Hyderabad. The problem is found to be more severe in primary infections, particularly in dengue variant-2 virus (Denv-2). There is a simultaneous circulation of all four variants of the virus. This makes the virus hyper endemic,” said Dr Suneetha Narredddy, consultant (infectious diseases), Apollo Hospitals, Hyderabad. The strains present in Hyderabad are known to cause severe dengue fevers. The city had a few people getting infections with more than one strain at the same time, she added. Even as the threat of new strains of dengue looms large, a team of doctors at Gandhi medical college and hospital has found co-infection of dengue, chikungunya and salmonella (typhoid) in patients. Almost one in two dengue patients in Hyderabad suffer from co-infection and in such cases, they need simultaneous medicare. In the last three years researchers have found emergence of a new strain (clade D of dengue virus type 4). Also, a new genotype of dengue virus-4 has been isolated. Doctors warn that presence of all four variants (serotypes) of dengue virus will result in secondary infection, making matters worse. The dengue virus-4 has emerged as the most potent of the four variants, doctors said. Senior physician Dr Syamala Aiyanger said during an epidemic, multiple strains can circulate. Infection with one strain usually gives lifelong immunity against that strain, but only transient or brief immunity against other strains. This cross immunity is only partial. So, a person infected with one strain remains vulnerable to others and can be infected by all during their lifetime. A research study by a team from department of microbiology, Gandhi medical college and hospital, revealed that some of the dengue patients were also suffering from chikungunya and a few others showed triple co-infection with chikungunya and typhoid. About 44% of the people, studied as part of the research, had acute dengue, 29% had chikungunya and 15% had typhoid. It also revealed that one in eight dengue patients was also suffering from chikungunya, one in 16 had chikungunya and typhoid and one in 20 patients had typhoid and dengue. “The drastic increase in dengue infection could be partly attributed to geographic expansion of the vector (mosquito) due to increasing urbanisation, unavailability of specific antiviral therapies, licensed dengue vaccine, and poor understanding of the host immune responses,” said RA Khan from department of biotechnology and bioinformatics, University of Hyderabad, in his research study that unravelled the role of a protein (dengue virus EDIII) in the spread of dengue. The UoH study could also help in development of new drugs to fight the dengue menace. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Dengue outbreak: DMC urges people to not panic | Dehradun News - Times of India
Content: DEHRADUN: In view of the rising dengue cases in the city, Dehradun Municipal Corporation (DMC) officials held a press conference in the DMC premises on Friday to urge Doonites to not panic. The officials assured the public that the situation is well under control. Speaking on the occasion, Dehradun mayor Sunil Uniyal Gama said, “At present, there is a sense of fear among the public regarding the dengue virus but we want to assure everybody that the situation is totally under control. The DMC has 108 fogging machines and each ward has been allotted a machine. Dengue virus can be controlled by following some simple measures.” The doctors present at the press conference highlighted some of the preventive measures and debunked a few popular myths regarding the disease. Dr. Vipul Kandwal, gastro-surgeon at Arogyadham Hospital told TOI, “There is an atmosphere of fear for no reason. Most of the people are catching normal viral fever and not dengue fever. I request the people to consult a doctor when they feel uneasy and not decide medication on their own.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: 18 new swine flu cases from Lucknow | Lucknow News - Times of India
Content: LUCKNOW: Lucknow's tally of swine flu patients reached 225 since January this year, after 18 new H1N1 cases were reported from the city on Monday. In the month of February, 196 swine flu positive cases have been reported from Lucknow. Of the new cases reported on Monday, seven patients were admitted to different medical facilities, while the health department said that the remaining patients were recuperating at their homes. The new cases included two patients who were residents of the Sanjay Gandhi Postgraduate Institute of Medical Sciences campus. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Third dengue den found bang on KGMU campus | Lucknow News - Times of India
Content: LUCKNOW: Larvae of the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which is a carrier of the deadly dengue virus, were found at TG Hostel on King George's Medical University (KGMU) campus on Thursday, a day after a vector den was spotted in the parking lot of the cardiovascular and thoracic surgery department. This is the third time since July that an Aedes breeding ground was found at KGMU, which has been served three notices in three months, while an employee also tested positive for dengue fever on Wednesday. The warning signs notwithstanding, the university seems to be doing precious little to contain the sting menace. Spokesperson for KGMU Sheetal Verma told TOI that the university was looking into the matter. "Instructions have been issued to sanitation workers to clean every corner of the campus. They will also identify spots where water is accumulating (in unused or abandoned containers) and submit reports," she said. Apart from the medical institution, where the mosquito larvae were found breeding in coolers, the health department has red-flagged 32 other spots in the city that are conducive to Aedes breeding. Notices have been slapped on all the 33 places, eight of them prominent addresses. Additional chief medical officer DK Bajpai said the health department's drive would continue till October. "Those responsible (for these mosquito breeding ground) have been served notices. They have to sanitise their premises within 24 hours. Our team will revisit these places and repeat offenders will be penalised," he added. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: West Rajasthan on alert after Congo fever in Pakistan, Gujarat | Jaipur News - Times of India
Content: JAIPUR: An alert on Crimean-Congo haemorrhagic fever (CCHF) has been sounded in western Rajasthan as border areas in Pakistan and in Gujarat have reported Congo fever cases in increased numbers. Even the Centre is keeping an eye on the fever. The Centre has sent a two-member team of National Centre for Disease Control, which reached Jodhpur on Thursday to assess the situation. The border districts such as Jaisalmer are also on alert. “We have issued directions to all our officials to remain alert on CCHF. Doctors have been told to remain alert if a patient with CCHF-like symptoms comes to them for treatment,” said Dr BK Barupal, chief medical health officer, Jaisalmer. CCHF is a disease caused by a tick-borne virus (Nairovirus) of the Bunyaviridae family. A 32-year-old person, resident of Molana Azad Nagar, was suffering from CCHF-like symptoms went for treatment to a registered medical practitioner on August 14. He did not get relief and went to government-run MDM Hospital. Following that, he rushed to Ahmedabad for further treatment, where the doctors took his sample and sent it to National Institute of Virology in Pune, where he tested positive for CCHF. Claiming that the situation is under control, the health department sent a team headed by Dr Praveen Aswal, nodal officer, Integrated Disease Surveillance Programme (IDSP) to Jodhpur, which has returned to Jaipur. “The team conducted the survey and found two more persons with symptoms of CCHF from the same family of the 32-year-old person. They have also been sent to Ahmedabad for treatment,” said Dr VK Mathur, director (health), health department. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Cuddalore man tests negative for nipah virus | Puducherry News - Times of India
Content: PUDUCHERRY: The 52-year-old resident of Cuddalore district, who was admitted at the Jawaharlal institute of postgraduate medical education and research (Jipmer) here with flu symptoms akin to that of nipah infection, tested negative for nipah virus. The National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, which tested the samples of the patient sent by Jipmer declared that the patient has not been infected with nipah virus. NIV’s microbiology department, which received the samples of serum, endotracheal aspirate, CSF and urine of the patient on June 13, tested them and declared that the patient tested negative for Nipah infection. The patient identified as Natarajan from Cuddalore district, who was working in Guruvayur in Kerala where a patient tested positive for nipah infection was admitted to Jipmer in a semiconscious state on Sunday. His condition continues to be in a critical state as on Friday. He is on ventilator support at the isolation ward in the institute. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Five students test positive for H1N1 virus in Kasaragod | Kozhikode News - Times of India
Content: KOZHIKODE: H1N1 virus infection has been confirmed in five students of Jawahar Navodaya Vidyalaya (JNV) at Periya in Kasaragod on Sunday. Now, the total number of confirmed H1N1 cases in Kasaragod district reported this month has rose to10. The swab test conducted at Manipal Virology Lab confirmed the infection in the five students. One of them has been admitted to Government District Hospital, Kanhangad and another to a private hospital. The other three are at one of the isolation wards at the school. Around 68 students of the school with symptoms of the disease have been kept under observation in the temporary isolation wards opened at the school hostel. The residential school has around 520 students and over 200 staff members. Health department has deployed additional doctors and staff members to monitor the students kept under observation. Kasaragod district medical officer Dr A P Dinesh Kumar said all the preventive measures have been put in place in the wake of the disease outbreak at the school. “The students have been asked to remain at school hostel itself to avoid chances of family members contracting the disease,” he said, adding that the situation was under control and public need not panic. School principal K M Vijaya Krishnan said that the students confirmed with the infection belonged to Class VIII and Class IX while those with suspected symptoms were from Class VI and above. “We have informed the deputy commissioner of the Navodaya Vidyalaya Samiti about the situation,” he said when asked whether the outbreak will affect the board exams of the students. Meanwhile, Kasaragod district collector has convened a meeting at Kanhangad taluk office on Monday to help spread awareness about the disease among parents and alleviate their concerns. K Kunhiraman MLA has urged the district medical officer to appoint sufficient number of doctors at the school. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Chandipura virus:  Chandipura virus: NIV paper raises alarm on male sandflies | Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content: AHMEDABAD: Gujarat’s health department should be worried before the next cycle of Chandipura virus infections strikes. A recent paper published by the National Institute of Virology (NIV), Pune, has reported Sergentomyia species of sandflies and especially the male of the species to be potential vector for the rapid spread of the disease. Already two children have died due to encephalitic illness or inflammation of the brain, caused by the Chandipura virus this year in Rustampura village in Vadodara district in July. NIV researchers Rekha Damle, Vasudha Sankararaman, Vandana Bhide, Vinayak Jadhav, Atul Walimbe, and Mangesh Gokhale had analysed 277 sandfly species collected from Dahod, Vadodara and Panchmahal districts. The report says, “This is probably the first report from India of male sandflies testing positive for the CHPV genome.” It adds further, “Positive male sandflies have been reported in Pakistan and Iran. This finding signifies vertical transmission of the Chandipura virus among sandflies, which facilitates the establishment and spread of the disease.” The NIV warning now requires the Gujarat veterinary department to intensify vector control measures in stables, cowsheds and store houses in rural houses, especially those which are made of mud and may host the sandflies within crevices. Between July and August this year, Dahod, Panchmahals and Vadodara districts reported a total of six Chandipura virus cases. An internal report prepared by the state’s health department, has reported these cases from Rustampura village, and one case each at Malnahudi Faliya, Tekar Falyu and Balisana in Panchmahals district; and Belisana village in Zalod taluka of Dahod. Each time these cases were detected, kuccha homes — usually made of mud — within 100 metres of where the virus struck are being dusted with malathion to kill sandflies, which live in cracks in cattle sheds and generally bite humans at night. In the tribal district of Panchmahal, according to the state government report, there were five deaths reported in 2009, four in 2010, and a single case and no deaths in 2013. News Title: Guidelines issued for government-run hospitals in Bhopal | Bhopal News - Times of India
Content: BHOPAL: District collector Tarun Pithode ordered a review of infrastructure, manpower and facilities being provided in government-run hospitals and health centres in the state capital on Wednesday. The directive comes following heavy rains in Bhopal and reports of poor conditions of some hospitals. The district administration is gearing up to pre-empt vector-borne and viral influenza outbreaks. In a meeting on Wednesday, Pithode instructed naib tehsildars, tehsildars and SDMs to conduct the inspection and present a status report within a week’s time. A check of health care setups and their preparedness for combating disease outbreaks would also be undertaken. There are about 35 government-run hospitals and sub-centres in the state capital. “Efforts will be made to improve the system based on the inspection report,” said Pithode, who as collector is part of various committees in these hospitals. The fact finding report will entail details on the number of doctors in these hospitals, availability of medicines, implementation of various government health schemes, facility provided to patients, arrangements of prescriptions, medicine distribution counters and availability of beds along with special wards for H1N1 and vector-borne infected patients. Cleanliness and hygiene in hospitals has been an issue in the state capital. Water seepage has been reported in many of them, which could increase the threat of hospital acquired infections, according to health department officials. Canteen facilities and availability of drinking water, streetlights and other aspects would also be reviewed by the officials. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: KGMU, Alambagh thana among 12 dengue dens | Lucknow News - Times of India
Content: LUCKNOW: A health department inspection on Wednesday found larvae of Aedes aegypti — vector for dengue virus — at 12 prominent places, including King George’s Medical University (KGMU). This came on a day when one more person tested positive for dengue taking the patient count to 37 since July. The fresh case was reported from the parking lot of cardiovascular and thoracic surgery department of KGMU. A 29-year-old employee, who resides in staff quarters on the campus, was tested positive. Earlier, KGMU was issued warning to keep the campus clean, when larvae was found from a few hospital wards and departments on July 15. The larvae was also found on the campuses of three other hospitals — Era’s Medical College and servant quarters of TB hospital in Thakurganj and Balrampur hospital. Other places include MLA hostel in Rajendranagar, staff quarters of 35th & 32nd battalion of Provincial Arms Constabulary, Alambagh police station, Shiksha Bhawan near City Station, UP State Agro Industrial office, an automobile shop in Husainganj and a building housing office of an NGO in Thakurganj. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Vector fight fails to take off amid blame game in Lucknow | Lucknow News - Times of India
Content: LUCKNOW: Dengue fever is stalking the city, but its health and hygiene guardians seem too busy in their little slugfest to contain a looming outbreak. The district health department and the Lucknow Municipal Corporation (LMC) had promised to launch a coordinated attack on the Aedes aegypti mosquito, which carries the dengue virus, from September 2. Forty-eight hours have lapsed since, but spraying of larvicides and fogging that can eliminate vector breeding dens haven’t been done. Almost as a reminder of institutional inefficiency, five more persons tested positive in the city on Tuesday. The health authorities and LMC had worked in tandem in July, which saw eight dengues cases. In the absence of a coordinated exercise in August, the last week of the month alone saw 14 cases. That jolted the two government agencies out of slumber. They quickly pledged a joint drive from Monday only to renege on the promise, leaving citizens at the mercy of the virulent virus. Health officials claimed that at a meeting on Friday, it was decided that the LMC would provide a team each in all the 110 wards of the city for the drive. “The LMC did not fulfil its commitment,” said DK Bajpai, additional chief medical officer, Lucknow. Civic officials said the health department never asked them for manpower in writing. “We cannot deploy teams without a formal letter of request. Nevertheless, we have contacted the health department on our own (on Tuesday) and resolved the issue. We will begin the drive from Wednesday,” said LMC health officer S K Rawat. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Mysuru scientist tests formulation to tackle papaya virus | Mysuru News - Times of India
Content: MYSURU: The fructification of a city-based scientist’s decade-long research is bound to enrich the fruit of many a farmer’s labour, quite literally – Vasanth Kumar Thimakapura’s plant-based eco-friendly formulation is being touted as the preventive remedy against the much-dreaded Papaya Ring Spot Virus (PRV), a bane for ryots dependent on the horticulture crop for their fortunes. Papaya is a biennial crop, and affliction by PRSV is a commonly reported problem in South Karnataka. Thimakapura averred that the formulation he has come up with is non-toxic, and can help control the spread of virus in other crops such as beans, tomatoes, cucumbers, orchids among others. President of the University of Mysore Old Students’ Association, and director of the technical wing of Green Lifescience Technologies, Thimakapura was determined to come up with a remedy for PRSV, a pestilent menace that is found across the world. For Thimakapura, the greatest reward for his work has been the results that farmers have reported after using his formulation for the past two years. “It has already been tested by farmers across India. This is besides many of the in-house trials that we have conducted,” said the scientist. What sets the formulation – Thimakapura has named it ‘PowerPlus’ – apart is that it helps prevent the onslaught by the virus, and can help cure those plants blighted by it. Unaffected papaya plants in his plot growing beside those affected by PSRV, Thimakapura said, attested to the efficacy of his formulation. “The virus has the potential to trigger an epidemic. As of now, there is no variety of papaya that is resistant to the virus, nor is there a foolproof mechanism that can help protect them from its threat. So, I hope that my product will serve as a boon for farmers,” he said. Consequences of virus infectionStunted growth, and lack of fruit-breaking ability are two of the most disastrous consequences of affliction by the Papaya Ring Spot Virus (PSRV) in papaya plants. Fruits borne by plants infected by the virus often exhibit clear signs of the disease: These include a discernible change in its taste, bumps and characteristic ring-shaped spots on the skin. PSRV spreads through an insect vector at an exponential rate, and all it takes for an entire plot to grow infested is a small clutch of PSRV-blighted plants. “Farmers dread it because it is impossible to contain its spread,” Vasanth Kumar Thimakapura said.
