News Title: Rajasthan: Suspected Congo fever virus samples sent to Pune for test | Jaipur News - Times of India
Content: JAIPUR: Samples of suspected cases of Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) virus will be sent to National Institute of Virology (NIV) in Pune for test as there is no such facility available at government’s hospital in the state. It is quite challenging for the health authorities to diagnose CCHF cases clinically as it has more or less same symptoms of dengue and scrub typhus, which are quite common in the state. Acknowledging that CCHF has epidemic potential, the health department has started taking measures for its diagnosis and treatment. Ribavirin is a medicine, which is effective in treatment of CCHF, but it is unavailable in most of the parts of the state. However, the health department claimed that in Jodhpur, they have made Ribavirin available where one case of CCHF has been diagnosed and two other suspected cases are undergoing treatment at a hospital in Ahmedabad. “We have it in Jodhpur and it is also available in market in Jaipur,” said the official. Moreover, after a 32-year-old person tested positive for CCHF from Jodhpur’s outskirt’s area, the health department has alerted all the officials across the state on CCHF and other zoonotic diseases. “Since CCHF, dengue, scrub typhus and other such diseases have similar symptoms, it is quite difficult to diagnose CCHF clinically. So, we have directed the officials to conduct test of dengue and other seasonal diseases first to rule out them first. If the patient tests negative for seasonal diseases, we will take it as suspected case of zoonotic disease,” said the official Besides, the health department is conducting door to door survey in the CCHF affected areas. On September 2, the health department has issued directions to all the chief medical health officers across the state for conducting anti-larvae activities for preventing spread of vector-borne diseases including fogging. The animal husbandry department has also been roped in to tackle the menace of zoonotic diseases. They are conducting activities to kill ticks as CCHF and other such diseases are transmitted from infected ticks to healthy livestock and from livestock, it is transmitted to humans. News Title: Doctor, three others test positive for Congo virus in Gujarat | Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content: AHMEDABAD/RAJKOT: A resident doctor of M P Shah Medical College in Jamnagar, who was serving in adjoining G G Hospital, tested positive of Crimean–Congo Haemorrhagic Fever (CCHF) on Monday night. This is at a time when three patients have tested positive in Ahmedabad’ SVP Hospital. According to Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation officials, two of the patients who were under treatment at at SVP are form Halvad and one is from Rajasthan. All of them, including Jamnagar’ Dr Jagruti Parmar (27), were confirmed CCHF positive by the National Institute of Virology. The total number of CCHF patients in Gujarat has reached to eight, according to a Gujarat health department official. Also, three people have died in the state due to CCHF. According to officials 52 persons have been tested negative of which four were doctors. In Jamnagar, Parmar was admitted in a hospital since past eight days where she was being treated for fever. Dr Nandini Desai, dean of M P Shah Medical College said, “She treated a patient who had symptoms similar to CCHF. However, before we could send the sample to Pune, the patient died. She too got sick and her report tested CCHF positive.” According to Desai, Parmar was recovering and her condition was stable. The hospital also did line listing in which all the medical and para medical staff who were on duty in treatment of suspected CCHF patients are checked and did medical check-up of the family members of the patient who died. There has been one CCHF positive case and one suspected death in Jamnagar district. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: ‘Zika risk underplayed, can prove fatal’ | Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content: AHMEDABAD: Next month, it will be a year since Ahmedabad reported a single Zika case; it was detected in Amraiwadi in October 2018. That year, Gujarat’s neighbours Rajasthan and MP recorded a major Zika virus outbreak and together accounted for 300 cases. Four experts now warn that the “the next large Zika virus epidemic may be taking off in India.” Zika virus is dreaded for causing microcephaly in newborns and is largely spread by the Aedes aegypti mosquito. A study published in the May edition of the journal called ‘Cell’ warns against being complacent about a single research conclusion from Chinese Academy of Sciences professor L Yuan, who had studied a single mutation responsible for microcephaly. TimesViewLast year in October there were two major Zika virus outbreaks in neighbouring states Rajasthan and Madhya Pradesh. Recently reputed scientific institutions have forewarned presence of both Asian and African Zika viral strain in the country. With these factors in mind health authorities should begin large scale Zika awareness drives among vulnerable pregnant women population. In Ahmedabad, which has been the epicentre for Zika outbreak in India, there are 1.2 lakh pregnant women with the civic authority’s surveillance system. It is an irony that government public display boards are yet to caution public against Zika prominently along with dengue and chikunguniya. The ‘Cell’ study said of the interpretation of Yuan’s work: “It appears to be misleading Indian public health officials into believing that ZikV in India is not dangerous to fetuses, thereby creating a situation where pregnant women may not be properly supported and educated on ways to protect themselves.” The ‘Cell’ report, in fact, has quoted five recent studies that suggest that ZikV strains without the S139N mutation can cause birth defects. By December 2018, nearly 100 pregnant women were reported to be infected with ZikV in India. The first three ZikV cases, which included two pregnant women, were reported from Ahmedabad between November 2016 and February 2017. The Aedes aegypti mosquito, common in homes, also spreads dengue and chikungunya viruses. The strong cautionary message comes from global disease experts of America’s Yale School of Public Health, Bangalore’s Centre for Ecological Sciences of Indian Institute of Science, Australia’s infectious disease research team, and Brazil’s Centre Instituto Goncalo Moniz. The experts’ research states, “Putting too much onus on a single mutation could enhance a crisis in India.” Last year, Indian public health authorities, the study states, had “sequenced five Zika virus isolates from Rajasthan and concluded that the virus cannot cause microcephaly unless the virus has mutation.” The research paper was authored by Professor of epidemiology (microbial diseases) Albert Ko and Nathan D Grubaugh of Yale, Farah Ishtiaq of Indian Institute of Science, and Yin Xiang Setoh of school of chemistry and molecular biosciences, Queensland University, Australia. The study concludes that “Not only should we be vigilant about the threat of future ZikV spread, but also of the spread of misinformation that could put many vulnerable populations at risk.” Download The Times of India News App for Latest City News.

News Title: Identified! Mosquito causing Zika in Ahmedabad is Aedes | Ahmedabad News - Times of India
Content: AHMEDABAD: It was known that aedes aegypti mosquito carried dreaded Zika virus, the first case of which in India was recorded in Ahmedabad in 2016. Now, scientists have pinpointed that it is Aedes (Stegomyia) aegypti from aedes family which is responsible for Zika cases in Indian subcontinent. Teams of National Institute of Malaria Research and Indian Council of Medical Research in research published in the August 2019 edition of Elsevier’s journal ‘Actatropica’ named this mosquito for the Zika outbreak in Jaipur last year. Between November 2016, when Zika virus was first detected in the country in an Ahmedabad based 34-year-old pregnant woman, and 2017 Tamil Nadu Zika detection, 18,000 aedes mosquitoes were screened. None were found to be Zika carriers. In 2018, 522 aedes mosquitoes studied during Jaipur outbreak by scientists helped nail the Zika culprits. News Title: Alert in Bijnor after woman tests positive for swine flu | Meerut News - Times of India
Content: BIJNOR: A Bijnor-based woman who has been diagnosed with swine flu is recuperating in a Meerut-based hospital, according to health department sources. With the detection of a swine flu case in Bijnordistrict, health department has directed its staff to be alert while dealing with patients suffering from fever, cough and bodyaches, which are also symptoms of other forms of flu. At the same time, 67 beds have been reserved for the patients here. A team of health department visited the colony where woman resides. The team conducted a check-up of the residents on Friday. The case came to the fore after Meerut’s CMO wrote to his Bijnor counterpart, Vijay Yadav, informing him that the patient had tested positive for swine flu and suggested that he look into the matter. TOI has learnt that the 53-year-old woman is a resident of Saket colony and was admitted to Meerut’s Metro Hospital for treatment. She has a history of lung ailment for the past five years. A few days ago, she came down with fever and was admitted to the Meerut hospital. When the Meerut heath department came to know about her condition, it sounded the Bijnor administration on Friday. According to Bijnor CMO Vijay Yadav, “We have reserved 67 beds in the district hospital and community health centres to deal with this disease and put our staff on alert. A rapid response team was sent to the colony concerned to check the other residents. I have instructed my subordinates to launch an awareness programme about this contagious viral disease in the district.” According to officials, the term swine flu refers to influenza among pigs. Occasionally, pigs transmit influenza viruses to humans. In early 2009, scientists recognized a particular strain of the flu virus, known as H1N1. This virus is actually a combination of viruses from pigs, birds and humans. During the 2009-10 flu season, H1N1 virus caused respiratory infection among humans. In August 2010, the World Health Organization declared it as pandemic. The signs and symptoms of swine flu are similar to those of infections caused by other flu strains and can include fever (but not always), chills, cough, sore throat, runny or stuffy nose, watery red eyes, body ache, headache, fatigue, diarrhea, nausea and vomiting. Flu symptoms develop in about one to three days after one is infected. The virus spreads from person to person either by inhaling it or by touching surfaces contaminated with the virus (in the form of infected droplets that are expelled into the air through coughing or sneezing). It is not fatal but children, pregnant women and the elderly are at risk from H1N1 virus for it can lead to complications and death. Health department has advised that to protect oneself from contracting swine flu, one must cover one’s nose and mouth in crowded areas, wash hands frequently with soap and water, avoid touching one’s eyes, nose or mouth and avoid contact with sick people. News Title: Deadliest virus in history threatens global pork industry - Times of India
Content: NEW DELHI: A deadly pig virus that jumped from Africa to Europe is now ravaging China’s $128-billion pork industry and spreading to other Asian countries, an unprecedented disaster that has devastated global food chains and has prompted countries to slaughter millions of pigs. Prices are expected to soar from the food markets of Hong Kong to American dinner tables . Outbreaks have been reported in Vietnam, Mongolia, Cambodia, Hong Kong, and also China — the world’s biggest pork producer and consumer. Checkpoints, sniffer dogs and strict import bans have been deployed in a desperate bid to control its spread. But the disease has already hit most provinces in China, reducing pork production by 30% according to some. CAN THE VIRUS AFFECT HUMANS?While the virus doesn’t harm humans even if they eat tainted pork, the fatality rate in pigs means it could destroy the region’s pork industry. BOOST FOR BEEF & POULTRYExports of these meats are on the rise as suppliers scramble to fill the deficit in a pork-hungry region. DAIRY COWS FOR BEEF?Some reports have claimed that China’s farmers may have started slaughtering their own dairy cows for beef. WHO’S IMMEDIATELY AFFECTED?Countries like China, Vietnam, S Korea, Japan, Taiwan, N Korea, Cambodia, Hong Kong, Mongolia. The US is also soon expected to feel the pinch — likely around Christmas when people buy holiday hams. CAN IT BE CURED?Despite 50 years of research, there’s no vaccine for it, and it might take decades to develop one. "It’s spreading like wildfire in Asia because... the pig is the garbage truck of Asia," says Simon Quilty, Australia based meat and livestock quality analyst. A whopping 1 million pigs have been killed since the first outbreak in China in August last year, a number widely considered an underestimate. On the other hand, Vietnam has culled 2 million pigs, 6% of its swine population. China has also experienced 40% surge in pig prices year on-year. An estimated 200 million pigs could be culled in China — more than half its swine population. The country supplies around 50% of the world’s pork.
